nodeDataArray.text: Dangers of Stochastic Parrots
Trend of Increasing LM Size
From n-gram to neural LMs to Transformer LMs
Driven by increasing performance on benchmarks
Examples: BERT, GPT-2/3, Switch-C
Multilingual variants exist but don't address language inclusion issues
Efforts to reduce model size still rely on large data and processing power
Environmental and Financial Costs
High energy consumption and carbon footprint
Disproportionately impact marginalized communities
Need to prioritize energy efficiency and cost reduction
Unfathomable Training Data
Size doesn't guarantee diversity
Internet access and participation are not evenly distributed
Moderation practices can marginalize certain groups
Filtering practices can further attenuate marginalized voices
Static data can't keep up with changing social views
Social movements influence language and framing
LMs risk reifying outdated views
Encoding bias
LMs learn and amplify biases present in training data
Auditing for bias is challenging and context-dependent
Need for curation, documentation, and accountability
Invest resources in careful data selection and documentation
Avoid relying solely on massive datasets
Misleading Performance and the Illusion of Understanding
LMs excel at manipulating linguistic form, not understanding meaning
High performance on benchmarks can be misleading
Focus on understanding the mechanisms behind performance is crucial
Stochastic Parrots: Risks and Harms
Coherence in the eye of the beholder
Humans interpret LM output as meaningful despite lack of intent
Risks and harms of deploying LMs
Amplification of biases and harmful stereotypes
Generation of abusive language and hate speech
Potential for misuse by bad actors (e.g., propaganda, extremism)
Risks in machine translation due to fluency masking errors
Privacy risks from memorization of training data
Paths Forward: Towards Responsible LM Development
Shift to careful planning and consideration of impacts
Prioritize energy efficiency and resource allocation
Focus on data curation and documentation
Engage in value sensitive design and stakeholder consultation
Explore alternative approaches and dual-use scenarios
Allocate effort to harm mitigation and responsible use
